values: Only time for a quick one - hi, how is everyone? - but I just wanted to say this is a damn good week to buy the Beano too, as I have not one, not two, not six million and twelve, but FIVE pages in this week's issue. Oh yeeeeaah! My two-page Minnie is in there, along with a two-page Ratz and a Johnny Bean. Never again will I pwn teh b34n0 in such a manner, so get it while it's hot!

Not the current issue, at any rate. For, yes, this is the week that the mystery strip I've been working on since March finally makes its entrance. Ladies and gentlemen, I give you "Johnny Bean from Happy Bunny Green", charming tales of life in a cosy rural idyll and the little hoody bastard who ruins it on a weekly basis. It's a departure in format from normal Beano strips, but I think it has loads of potential - well, I would say that, wouldn't I? Plus, this week's Beano has a free Halloween kit with a glow-in-the-dark plastic skeleton, so there's really no excuse not to buy it (unless you're frightened of skeletons or things that glow in the dark). (Website's updated too) That's my name there on the contents page, right under Tom Paterson's. Certain readers of this blog will instantly know how cool that is ;)

Too late in the evening for a long post - got a comics convention coming up next weekend, so expect something juicier after that. In the meantime, I've updated my site with quite a lot of new stuff tonight, so go have a snuffle through all that. Oyasumi!

As Oscar Wilde once put it, to have one blog is unfortunate, to have two is just plain geeky. Yes, I have made the momentous decision to attempt to rend my brain asunder and post all comicky news and views in a dedicated blog, retaining all other business on this one. The reasons for this are manifold - no, actually, there's just one. I want to be able to link to a blog on my website, but my LiveJournal one doesn't fit the bill (too much personal and non-comicky stuff on here that I don't necessarily want everyone to see). So, add this URL to your Bookmarks: panelbeat.blogspot.com I'll be putting up my first post, about the Comics Festival I just returned from in Spain, in the next few days.

Just a few new images, plus info on con appearances. Actually, I've been doing loads more artwork lately than I'm allowed to post on the site, but it'll get there eventually. A notable thing I've just finished, which I can't add yet but will when it's published, is a Les Pretend page for the Beano. Yes, my first crack at an established Beano character - quite an honour! In other arty news, I spent a glorious day at a place called Compton Verney in Warwickshire on Sunday, in the company of my life drawing class. We drank wine, ate grapes and sandwiches, basked in the sun... and found a bit of time for painting and sketching too. A most civilised day out. The weekend before that, Tim and I went to Whitby (seaside town up North - we go there every couple of years). It was the beginning of Whitby Folk Week, which is basically an excuse for British people to get together and be even more eccentric than usual. Like doing folk dancing, for instance. Dr Who-themed folk dancing... Marvellous. Finally, famous Brit comic writer/artist Bryan Talbot has just released a book of crazy stories about famous figures from the comics industry (involving such hot topics as nudity/fist fights/skeletons/Finnish people/drunkenness/insane fans/drugs - oh, and a Klingon drinking coffee). It's a bloody funny read whether you know anything about comic creators or not, and it's illustrated throughout by my erstwhile boss Mr Emerson (who appears in two stories, one involving Russia, nudity and a carrier bag). What more incentive could you need to pick up a copy ... from Amazon.com? ...from Amazon.co.uk?
Watch. Love. Never, ever get the song out of your head.

Despite rumours to the contrary. It's been a while, hasn't it? I doubt anyone will be surprised to hear that I've been very busy with drawing various things, attending various seminars, and travelling to London to watch various Japanese Ska bands (well, no, just the one of those actually:) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rJZgUpzqAyY&mode=related&search= We saw them in a MUCH smaller venue than this, only a few hundred people - but as you can see, in Japan they're popular enough to fill 10-15,000 capacity venues. w00t! Finally, a Japanese band that hasn't already disbanded by the time I find out about them (yes, I'm looking at you, Modern Choki Chokies). This is only really a short entry to say I'm off to Austria next week to escape the miserable weather we're having in Britain right now, to eat pork, and to spot a wolpertinger. Ooh missus! Oh, and I updated my site yesterday, so take a look at a few of the things I've been up to since the last entry. I HOPE by the time I next write in this journal, my new Beano strip will be running. Fingers crossed...

Yay, just made my first sale to MAD magazine! They're undecided yet as to whether I will get to draw the thing in question or not - I have to get some sketches prepared by next week, so they can see how I'd interpret it. But regardless, I still get paid for the idea itself, so w00t! 

Actually, I'm busy busy busy right now - I've got eight Beano annual pages on the go (the 2009 annual - yes, they plan that far ahead!) and of course the weekly strips themselves. Also, an old animator friend has just been in contact expressing an interest in us working together on something. I expect great things from this chap, as he did this, which is a minor work of genius:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eGlEZ6iDrJE

I also have a t-shirt with a picture of some meat on the front. So all is good.

A busy weekend, but a good one - no, a great one, I think. Tim and I arrived at the convention hall at 9.45 on Saturday to set up the Midlands Comics Collective stall - next thing I knew it was about one in the afternoon and I was wandering back from the con hotel with a cup of tea and a Bounty in my hand, having just given up an increasingly futile quest to find Shelley Bond (an editor from Vertigo - more about that in a mo). Many stalls to visit, including an increased presence of indies and self-published titles - always good to see - and many interesting bods from the industry to meet, including the luvverly Jamie Smart (premiering "Fat Chunk", the excellent minicomic for which I did the "Toy Parable" story a couple of months back), who is much taller than you would think he is, Mr Bryan Talbot (promoting his jaw-droppingly good "Alice in Sunderland" - buy it!), Glenn Fabry, and so on and so on. I held off on the inevitable spending on the Saturday, largely because I was too busy either manning the stall or wandering around chatting to people. Oh, I also picked up my comp copy of Accent UK's "Zombies" anthology, for which I did the "House of the Dead" story (you remember the one - it's on my site, anyway). Looks good. I'm undecided as to whether to put something in their next one, "Robots" - not a very inspiring subject for me... So anyway, evening came and we found ourselves in a huge group of StripSearchers, MC2 members and the odd comic artist (well, Hunt and John McCrea, as usual) having a chinese meal and swapping rude jokes and anecdotes. Then, upon returning to the hotel bar with some members of the gang, I found myself conversing with the mentioned-several-posts-back Lew Stringer (yes! I met him, finally! He, too, is luvverly!), and a jolly nice Viz artist named Paul Palmer. We basically agreed that a)we have the best job in the world, and b)we'd been drinking a lot. The evening wrapped up for me at about 1.30 (following a long, very inebriated conversation with Hunt about mad aunties and...er...not sure), at which point the comic artists had already almost drunk the bar dry. It's very dangerous letting people who work alone from home out into a social setting... Sunday. I was one of the few non-hungover people, which was lucky for me since I finally got to see Shelley - who looked at my portfolio and asked me to send her ideas and sketches for possible MINX titles. Ohhhh yeeeaaah! I also had interest from some publishers who might want me to do a 2-3 page illustrated biography of Edgar Allan Poe (sweet!), and a new inking/colouring gig lined up. So all in all - yeah! Woo! Comics rawk! Oh, if you'd like to see some piccies from the weekend, one of the Comics Collective guys out together a little slideshow - chekkiddout (under Convention Appearances): www.comicscollective.co.uk
A bit of new art (including swanky new Gilbert & Sullivan)! An opportunity for purchasing things! Um, that's about all actually. Now I have to go - I have a Comics Expo to prepare for...

Buy my stuff! Repeat, buy my stuff! Or not! But at the very least, go and have a look at it. Not much up yet, but it's a start - expect new designs to appear on a regular-ish basis.

I'm really looking forward to the new Pixar film coming out this June (or, if you're stuck in the UK like me, this October - bah! Disney might as well hand every animation fan in Britain a coupon saying "Please download this movie illegally"). I never did see Cars, because every time I saw a trailer I thought "I'm just not engaged with this. They're cars. They're freakish. Give me organic things, darmmit!" But Ratatouille is a whole different animal. Just in case you're not as familiar with it as you ought to be, here's the hi-res trailer:

http://disney.go.com/disneypictures/ratatouille/

And a neat little making-of clip, which demonstrates yet again how Pixar are such elegant problem solvers: 

http://progressive.totaleclips.com.edgesuite.net/100/b10070_b2z.mov

OK, so there's a few more lazy French stereotypes than I'd like, but hell, it's a great concept for a story, it looks amazing, and it's directed by Brad "The Incredibles" Bird. I say, bring it on!

Is this the first update for April? I do believe it is. OK, since the last entry, I've spent Easter on the east coast (appropriately), been to Barcelona with Doctor Tim, and (yesterday, in fact) went to a cartooning event in Shrewsbury, a nice little market town not too far from Brum. There's not much to say about the first two, except we ate, drank, walked and shopped, all of which are far more interesting to do yourself rather than hear about other people doing them. The cartooning event was fun, though - saw loads of cartoonists whose work I was familiar with, including Steve Bright (drew Bananaman for the Dandy until very recently), Pete Dredge, Noel Ford, Clive Collins (brother of Phil Collins, or so I'm told - gawrsh!) and Steve Best. Steve Bell from the Guardian was there too, and I was rather chuffed to hear that he told Hunt he's a fan of Ratz... he he! Nice! Speaking of which, since Mr Emerson is very busy at the mo, I'm getting to do another page by myself this week. Expect to see that on my website shortly. In the evening, as is customary for comic artists, we all piled into a pub and started drawing each other (well, piling into a pub and drinking is MORE customary, but we did that too). Now I'm not much good at drawing real people in real surroundings, but I'm told that it's important to learn how, 'cos then you might get hired to do caricatures at events, like weddings and such. Here's my current skill level - room for improvement, but not entirely piss-poor for two-minute drawings with no pencil roughs underneath. Then, when I'd drawn all the people nearby whose faces I could see clearly, I progressed to something a little more typical of my ouvre: And a good time was had by all (also, Hunt draw a great pic of Tim that makes him look like some kind of evil pixie. I'll scan that sometime). Now, I've got a chocka few weeks coming up - I want to set up a Cafe Press store linked to my site, and I've foolishly volunteered to put together a mini-comic for the Midlands Comics Collective in time for the big Comics Con in Bristol (which is a scant three weeks away). Plus, I have new Beano art(aside from Ratz), and new Gilbert and Sullivan, to do ASAP. So why am I still here? I'm off to make a start on some of this stuff! Keep checking back here for news on the Cafe Press situation, by the way...

Well, normally I'd let you get away with it. But this week's is the one with the Ratz page that was drawn entirely with my own fair hands (the spider one - you can see it on my website, but this version has colour and words and stuff). So if you're in the UK - blimmin' well go out and buy it! Actually I should've announced this days ago, as there's only two days before the next issue comes out. Never mind. Go! Shops! Now!

Hasn't it? My gosh, but hasn't a lot been happening. OK, so I thought when January was over I could chill out a bit, you know, bake some cakes, make a start on my novel and all that - boy howdy, was I wrong. Let's quickly review the events of the month, shall we: - Putting together my mini-comic - Finding a printer and getting said comic printed - Having a birthday - Preparing for the NY Comic Con - Doing new portfolio pages for the NY Comic Con - Going to the NY Comic Con And the usual stuff besides that, you know, the Beano work, life in general... So, those of you whose addresses I know will naturally get copies of Comic Pie (so the mini is named - don't ask me why, pies are just funny), and the rest of you will have to settle for seeing the cover on the front page of my website. It's been up there for a couple of weeks actually, I really should've got round to announcing that fact on my journal. But I didn't. Oh well. The Con was grrrreat, as was dear old NYC itself - although a complete contrast temperature-wise to when I went last summer, since it snowed some of the time. I showed my portfolio to people from Vertigo (actually went out to dinner with a Vertigo editor and his writer and artist cronies - sweet), MAD magazine, Archie Comics, Slave Labor and TokyoPop. All of them liked my work (or, let me put it this way, none of them said they didn't), although of course in this business in order to get a gig you have to be prepared to play the waiting game as to when the right project comes along for you. Still, I have sown the seeds, so I'll keep sending all these people updated sets of artwork on a semi-regular basis (as all good little comic artists are advised to do by their sensei), and see what fruits they bear. Speaking of bear (tenuous link here), I'll have a page in "Fat Chunk", the new comic being put out by the lovely Mr Jamie Smart of "Bear" fame. For those of you who've never read Bear, it's a comic about a teddy and a cat, and features lots of blood, faeces and cake. It's VERY VERY funny. Expect to see Fat Chunk premiering at Bristol in May. Also, I'm most likely going to have a new strip starting in the Beano before too long - a kind of spin on the "rotten tales for little kids" genre of entertainment, inspired (so sayeth the ed) by my Strawberry Shortcake piss-take from early January. I won't be writing it, but I will be drawing it all by myself. Yay me! I've also been allowed to draw and ink a Ratz page on my own for the first time too, so I'll alert you Brits to the week when that appears. Gosh, I think that'll do for the moment. I am happy - things are progressing well in Meats Land^_^ I'll be putting up some photos from the Comic Con very soon on Flickr, so keep your eye on either my website or this here journal to find out when that happens. In the meantime, this should give you a good idea as to the general tone of the thing.

Look, 30 comics on and I'm still alive! It's been a funny old month, but looking back on all the strips I'd say it's been a worthwhile activity - I've got some good new characters and ideas to play with from that lot and, more importantly, I have enough material to compile into a mini-comic. Yes! (Hopefully) in time for my trip to the New York Comics Con on February 22, I'm going to put the best strips into dead tree form to give out to unsuspecting editors. Question is, which strips are in and which are out? Obviously I need to concentrate on good artwork, but I don't want to miss out some  sketchier favourites. So, these are the definites so far (remember, I don't need 22 strips, just 22 pages to fill - so obviously, say, yesterday's would count as two pages).

 - The Happy Land of Fruitopia
 - Cat & M.O. mouse
 - Capybara (split over two pages)
 - Stupid things I believed
 - Fun with herpetology
 - Entertaining five year olds
 - Poe
 - Christmas with the horsemen
 - Jonathan Science
 - Justice Lunch

And on the "probably but not 100% sure" list:

 - Occam's razor
 - Pope Squad
 - Duck & Plover
 - X-13's Shaggy Rat Story
 - Fight Crab
 - Cupid

Any thoughts? Anyone got favourites not on the lists? I would include Forbidden Fruits, but the punchline sadly won't carry overseas and I don't want to change it. Remember, I need to fill 22 pages in total. Cheerz m'dears! And thanks to everyone who has supported this little endeavour in various ways, you've done a lot to keep me motivated in my weary moments^_^

For those of you who are curious about the adventures of the people in the House of the Dead, I've uploaded the remaining three pages (plus re-uploaded the first three, with speech balloons) to my site, along with a bit more Ratz stuff. Yeah! How's everyone liking the strip-a-day? I tell you, the Poe one nearly killed me - very stupid to attempt that one in a day (although I must confess, I wrote it on the Thursday, so I only had drawing and gathering reference material to do on Friday. Ha! ONLY had to do those things! Yeesh.) Also, I'm thinking of going to a comics convention in New York in February. A little impromptu, and a little expensive, but could be a good career move...

It's 2007. Whoa. Hope you all had a nice Christmas and New Year's Eve. It's late and I'm tired, so I won't rattle on about mine - suffice it to say, it was fun but busy, and wrapped up yesterday with a combination wedding/baptism for a friend and his youngest kid. Definitely a novel way to see in the new year... 

I'm rapidly losing the ability to type, but before I give up completly, allow me to remind you once again of the strip-a-day activity happening all month on my website. I suspect it might kill me, or at the very least make me want to never do a comic page ever again. But either way, I'm going to stick it out 'til the end - late nights, here I come!

Another teeny update to my website, for those who are interested. Also, I hereby announce my intent to create and upload a new comic strip every single day in January - I don't have a title for this ambitious activity yet, so let's call it "The lots of strips in January thingy". Any suggestions for subject matter for stories are welcome, although I make no promise they will be used^_^

On an unrelated topic, I saw Flushed Away yesterday. Disappointing, disappointing, disappointing. Weak screenplay and what looked like a real rush job on the animation front (although I acknowledge there were some very funny bits here and there - kudos in particular to the frogs). Here's hoping Aardman finally manage to ditch Dream-bloody-Works before attempting a new film>_<

Well. It's been a bit weird since the surrealness of IMAF a couple of weeks ago. The week after the ceremony, I pretty much had brain-freeze the whole time and didn't get a thing done except a Ratz page, but since then I've been doing other stuff... drawing a six-page zombie story... more Ratz... you know. Tim has returned from Korea in one piece, with tales of nasty food. The media's also taken a bit of an interest in the IMAF thing - even as I type this, there is an interview on local BBC radio with yours truly, that I recorded on Thursday. TOOOOOOO weird!! Tim's downstairs listening to it, but I can't bear to. I probably sound like a total retard, since I was running on pure nerves the whole time we were recording it. And I know my voice sounds appalling when recorded. So yeah. Weird. I'm going to spin this entry out until the interview is over and I can return downstairs. La la la la la la la...... ah yes, I'm actually going to be working in an office for a while up until the end of the year, doing illustrations in-house for a CD-Rom at Hi8us Midlands (the StripSearch people). That's pretty cool - I'd almost forgotten the heady thrill of fancying a cup of tea during the day and having SOMEONE ELSE make it. I really must get those cats trained better. Shit, that interview's still going on. Why won't I shut up? Whhhhyyyyy??? OK, that' enough spinning out. I'm going to put a CD on or something.
I refer you to the frontpage of my website. That is all.

OK, so. It's the MC2 launch party tomorrow, so I'm knee deep in last-minute preparations for that. Theatre on Friday. Visiting friends in London, and doing IMAF on Saturday and Sunday. Thursday was supposed to be seeing the Bonzo Dog Doo-Dah Band, but... wait for it... remember that G&S comic for IMAF? Well, it made it on the shortlist in the comic category! Wheeee!!! The awards ceremony is Thursday, so that's now become a London-and-no-Bonzos day... but hey, it's a damn good reason to miss it! Even if I don't win an actual prize, making the shortlist is a great CV booster. Aaaaaargh!! More news as it happens!

This week's Beano contains the first Ratz with my signature on it, and the first one I wrote (it's the "bling" one that's on my website, actually). Nice! And with only a few dialogue changes, too. 

What else can I write about? Hmm. Oh, such a busy day I had today. Proofreading, sending out invites to the MC2 launch party next week, life drawing class... and look at the time now! I should be off to bed. A very good night to you all. Wow, what a dull entry. I'll do better next time^_^

The Midlands Comics Collective's anthology, MC2, is now available to preorder on Amazon.co.uk. Woo! Seems kind of weird to see it on there... I doubt we'll sell many copies, but meh, that's not the point^_^ http://www.amazon.co.uk/exec/obidos/ASIN/0861661559/downthetubes Why it says downthetubes on the end, I have no idea. So anyway, it's Halloween today. I used to love Halloween when I was little, because I was seriously into witches and werewolves and stuff of that ilk. Now, with the cynicism of adulthood, I see it as a time to avoid being in my front room, so the light doesn't give away my presence when trick-or-treaters come. Ah, I kid, I kid. I actually bought myself a proper costume this year to wear to my friend Sarah's party (her birthday is October 27th, so she usually throws a Halloween-themed bash). It's an awesome purple and black witch's garb, with spiderweb lace and everything. If I had a photo, I'd put it up, but I don't. Aaaaanyway, since Tim's in Korea and I'm in the house by meself tonight, I'm probably going to watch horror DVDs while getting quietly drunk. But not too drunk, because I have a huge batch of proofreading coming in tomorrow. Finally: Harvard University. It's not as intellectual as you think. For a start, it paid me to write and draw this: Tee hee!

Yes, today marks my first ever Ratz in print (actually the second one I inked - which is a relief, because it's better than the first one I did. Although three's when I really started to get the hang of it). So, all of you Brits who are reading this, I demand you go out and buy a copy! NOW!! It's not one I wrote, by the way, so I take no responsibility for the story^_^

Update to the website today - a new Ratz (the Christmas special - and it's not even Hallowe'en yet, brrr!), and my entry to the Character Design section of the IMAF competition - this, and more besides: In other news, I've been commissioned by the bods at Harvard University (yes, THE Harvard) to do a two-page G&S comic for a limited-edition book they're putting out... I'm proofreading a book about designing computer games... Ratz is ongoing, of course... yes, keeping nicely busy. Mom keeps trying to get me to admit quitting my former job, but I don't. Hear that, mother? I! DON'T!! Drop it already! I've also been feeling a little nostalgic lately, and it's all to do with buildings. My old primary school was torn down this year (having been disused for quite some time), to make way for new housing. Plus, the hall of residence where I spent two of my years at uni, and in fact where I met Tim, is also in the process of being turned into rubble. Of course, neither place has had any part of my life for years and years, but even so... I guess it's the thought that no-one else will ever again have the experience of being there. Yep, a year of change all round.
Since the response to my G&S page has so far been pretty positive, I couldn't resist uploading the rest to my website. Run! Run, Lassie! Or little Timmy's going to die down that goshforsaken well!

Hello! Been quiet for a while, but my reasons are good, I've been slaving away on my entry for the International Mange and Anime festival (www.imaf.co.uk), a lavish six-page adaptation of one of my infamous Gilbert and Sullivan comics. Those of you used to the low production values of the originals should immediately notice a difference. Don't worry, though, it's still very silly^_^ Although it's been hard work, I've had a lot of fun learning new Photoshop tricks, and also discovered the joys of plundering the web for digital screentones and custom brushes. Although how manga-ka have the patience to cut out and stick Letraset tones is anyone's guess... maybe that's why they have armies of low-paid assistants.

Since I've been banging on about it for a while, I thought it was about time I actually showed peeps what "Ratz" looks like. This is the third one I've done, and it's probably the best of the three so far. Remember, it's my inks over Hunt's pencil drawings, so it's not quite my usual style - still, I'd like to think you could still tell I did it (not least because I get to sign them)^_^ You should just about be able to work out the plot without the speech balloons, it's not exactly Virginia Woolf...

Big update to my Website today. I've taken down a few older pics, reorganised some pages, added a lot of new stuff, and just generally done a lot of digital yardwork. And now I need a nice cup of tea. Tata!

I mean, my drawings are in print for a change, not my writing. Ilex Press have FINALLY released the Computer Cartoon Kit (I did the work for them last September and it was a short deadline then - oh well). Judging from the pics on the cover, they seem to have used my cat characters with very few changes. I'm looking forward to getting my complimentary copy!

Almost one year on from sending my submission, I finally got a rejection from Slave Labor last week. Well, I say last week... I actually got an email from the Editor-in-chief herself informing me that their records stated they sent a rejection letter on May 25th, but it seems to have been lost in the post. What's really galling is she said she remembered sending it because she wrote an accompanying letter herself rather than just a form rejection. Now I wasn't really expecting to get anywhere with this submission - I mean, let's face it, you have to be super-uber-lucky to get your own comic series commissioned from your first ever submission to a publisher - but I was at least hoping to get some useful feedback from it, which it sounds like I've been denied by cruel fate. POO. On the plus side, she said I've been flagged up on their database as "applicant with potential" and she'd like me to send them more stuff, so I'm chuffed about that. OK, brain in gear for a new pitch, methinks...

Also, I've finished Usborne for good now. The tree book was doing my head in and I have lots of projects lined up for the near future, so it seemed like the right time to do it. I've been writing stories for the Beano as well as inking them, so that's a little extra cash and good pracise for me (it's surprisingly hard to write short comic stories - try it if you don't believe me.) I'm going to try and get a few more writing gigs too, for some magazines I have my eye on. But I can't write any more right now, I'm too full of food - damn those all-you-can-eat Chinese buffets^_^;

Woo! Those of you in the UK may wish to pick up this week's copy of the Beano, featuring the premier of the strip I will be working on with Hunt Emerson, "Ratz". I completed my first page this week, it's been submitted to DC Thompson, and everything seems to be looking good - going to write some stories too, hopefully. Although the pay for writing a script is so laughably low, I'm not even going to mention it here. Anyway - BEANO! Britain's most famous comic! Eeeeee! I am chuffed! It'll be a good ten to twelve weeks before my page is printed, but you can be damn sure I'll be buying a handful of copies that week:D Apart from that, I've been working on the interminable Trees book for Usborne, continuing to stare at nekkid people in my life drawing classes, and learning me some new art skillz on the computer. This week's lesson: making cute pictures using vector graphics. Sure, it's the bastard offspring of Puffy Amiyumi and the Powerpuff Girls, but still cute, eh? What else... still got the episcleritis, bah... went to Southwold at the weekend, a quaint little seaside town full of deli's and yummy mummies... off to London this weekend... still need to update my website, bah again... saw Superman Returns (pretty good)... yeah! Things! I like things!

Been a while, eh?

Ah me, what's to be said (apart from it's too hot in this country right now to sit in front of a computer all day, and yet the alternative is doing the ironing this evening BLAAAAH). Since my last post, the following things have happened:

1) My parents had to have our pet dog of the last 13 and a half years put to sleep. This has been a very sad event for all of us, even though we knew it was coming (she was diagnosed with cancer of the liver back in May). On the plus side, for all but the last week of her life, Shula was as happy and lively as she's ever been, so her suffering wasn't prolonged. On the minus side - apart from the fact that she's dead - I was actually with her when she was euthanised, which was a horrible, horrible experience. Feeling down about this is part of the reason I haven't bothered posting for a while.

2) Another reason is that I just haven't done much art lately. I've been in communication with the editor of MAD magazine, who liked an idea I sent in (although it was too similar to something they'd already done), and asked me to send more. But only rough scribbles have come from that so far.

3) I saw Tokyo Godfathers. It's a brilliant, uplifting anime about three homeless people who find a baby on Christmas eve and go searching for its parents. It's by the same guy who did the equally good, but much more disturbing Paranoia Agent, Satoshi Kon.

4) I have been suffering from a condition called episcleritis, which basically makes your eye look like a red snooker ball. It's pretty harmless in itself, but it looks terrifying. And probably indicates I'll develop rheumatoid arthritis when I get older. Yay!

And... it's my last week at Usborne this week, which feels VERY weird. Will I cry on Friday? Place bets now! 

End. Art at some point.

New York, New York! A terrible town! The sky is brown and the water is brown! The cabs don't stop, they don't even slow down! New York, New York! It's a terrible town! - Jay and Alice, The Critic No, that's not true at all! Well, maybe the bit about the cabs. Indeedy, I have just returned from my very first trip to the States, and have found no part of it whatsoever to be terrible, except perhaps for the very exhausting flight back. We spent five nights in NYC, with two nights in Boston sandwiched in the middle. We were staying in Greenwich Village, which is a great area packed with high-quality delis and cafes, and also provided much amusement for me and Tim on the last day when my slightly shocked Dad got to witness the immense Pride parade. "Lesbians kissing in the street! Men holding hands eveywhere you look! I've never seen anything like it!" Bless. We did the stereotypical tourist sights - Staten Island ferry, Macy's, Times Square, Central Park, Ground Zero, Empire State etc - whilst finding enough time for shopping and EATING. Photo time I think. This was my breakfast on day one - DOOM MUFFIN. I soon learned to have something more sensible first thing in the morning. Typical NY scenery. One of the strangest things I found about being back in Birmingham was that I could see things near the horizon again. Tim and I went on the famous carousel in Central Park. Of course, I made him pose for this picture on the most demented-looking horse we could find. Did you know all American carousels turn anti-clockwise but all British ones turn clockwise? True, apparently. Yes, we ate at Spanky's. As well as having both a hilarious name and a hilarious poster, their meats are to die for. Or more likely, of. Much as I loved New York, Boston was my favourite. A lovely, verdant place, with super-friendly people, great shopping, lots of interesting history and - lucky for us - Cow Parade! It says "Cowtucket" on the side. Oh dear... Boston mixes the old and the new in a big way. We had, as the locals would say, a wicked good time in Boston. I'm very keen to return to the area and tour more of New England (ideally in the Autumn, but probably too expensive.) Still, since we took the Chinese Lucky Star bus there and back from New York, it didn't cost us much to visit this time round - $15 each way, bargain! Overall, what surprised me most was the number of cliches that the East Coast effortlessly exploded. Example: - Fat Americans. Nope. Well over 90% of the people I saw were slim, tanned and generally beautiful. Really does make us Brits look like pasty-faced oiks by comparison. - Unfriendly New Yorkers. Dad claimed he met a rude barman, but everyone me and Tim encountered was quite charming. - Dangerous New York. Frankly, I've felt less safe in Birmingham City Centre than riding the subway at midnight. And some of the cliches that were spot-on: - American portion control. It doesn't exist. Come on, what other country could offer you a three-pint soda for $1.79? - National obsession with peanut butter. I have never seen so many ways of mixing chocolate, peanut butter and caramel in my entire life. Hallelujah!! I only regret that I couldn't bring back any of the multitude of dreamy-sounding ice cream flavours that you can't buy in the UK. Still, I managed to stuff a carrier bag of candy bars, some biscuits and some cookie-dough Pop Tarts in my suitcase. And Dad got addicted to Gatorade. So yes, I would go again for sure. I think the South's next on the agenda, if we can just work out a decent itinerary. Once you've tried chicken-fried steak, there's no looking back. Thanks, Spanky's^_^

No, not beriberi - New York! Yes, Tim, me, and (bizarrely) my Dad are all off to The Large Fruit next month for a week of sightseeing and eating things like this. First time in the States for me and Dad, and Tim's only been to the arse-end of Texas, so it should be fun. We're spendng a couple days in Boston too, just to balance things out (and because it's near). Ah, here's some more news. I quit my job! That's right, as of July 28th I am no longer gainfully employed by Usborne Publishing. I must instead rely entirely on my art and maybe foraging skills to earn cash. Need an incentive to succeed much?? It'll be scary and exciting and several other adjectives, but I feel like the time is finally right. And if things don't work out, i can always find a new 9-5er. Bleh. On a slightly related topic, I bought two pages of artwork from the gorgeous Serenity Rose comic to celebrate my attempt to grasp the Comic Dream, and the artist hand-drew me a sketch wishing me luck! Eeee! Lookit! So, everyone take a moment to contemplate what a lovely chap Aaron Alexovich is. You wouldn't get that kind of service from the Vasquez.

I need a break right about now. No sooner was I done with the exhibition preparations, but I had to do an A3 page of art for Street Comic, deadline today. Hours and hours of work later, and it's done. Without wishing to sound unduly boastful, I think it's my best piece of comic art to date. (Although the fact that it's in full colour probably helps matters.) It's up on my website, along with a bunch of other new stuff, so checkiddout. If Street Comic is well received, I hope to get a paid contract doing this strip. I've got lots of plots lined up for The Sinistors should the opportunity to use them arise. In other news - Best. It helps to have a fast connection, but even if you don't they're worth the wait. Special recommendations: the Rip Slyme video with the puppets, chicken/frog toilet (in the archive), and the Bear Sanctuary ad. Also, there's a trailer for The Calamari Wrestler, the demented movie I mentioned a couple of entries back. Finally - further proof that Disney is intent on brutally raping its own heritage with a splintered broomhandle. I'm just waiting until they make "Snow White 2: Snow Whiter" to know for sure the job's complete.

Book: The Pirates! In an Adventure with Scientists www.amazon.co.uk/exec/obidos/ASIN/0753818701/qid=1141045643/sr=8-1/ref=sr_8_xs_ap_i1_xgl/203-4782995-0231947 A small but perfectly-formed tome, which can be read in about two hours but will leave a happy glow that lasts many months. Some outrageously stupid pirates go to Victorian London with Charles Darwin, who is attempting to prove that a monkey in a nice suit can be passed off as a human. Lots of ham is eaten (in fact, the Pirate Captain's personal motto is "I like ham".) Film: Fear and Trembling www.amazon.co.uk/exec/obidos/ASIN/B0007TFJ46/qid=1141046184/sr=1-1/ref=sr_1_10_1/203-4782995-0231947 Based on the semi-autobiographical novel of the same name, this follows a Belgian girl called Amelie as she struggles to fit into the incomprehensible world of Japanese office life as a misfit foreigner. Not only is it painfully funny (and often just painful), the two female leads are endlessly amazing to look at. The title of the film, if you're wondering, refers to the demeanour one was traditionally supposed to adopt when approaching the Emperor. Finally: more art arriving on my Website very soon.
